job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Jefferson City, MO
pros: Lincoln University of Missouri's Department of Agriculture has a lot of lab equipment that makes learning and doing research easy.
cons: Some of the labs need upgrades.
University is completely mismanaged from top to bottom

job_title: Adult Education Teacher in Fulton, MO
pros: Flexible hours, great team, and nice supervisor
cons: Part-time, evenings, work with offender population

review_title: Work here if you want to get a good education
job_title: Sales Associate/Animal Husbandry in Jefferson City, MO
pros: Flexible, unique, cost efficient, genuine, hard working
cons: Unorganized, Poor communication, poor management, mediocre staff

pros: Was able to work from home in needed situations. Holidays are great.
cons: Insurance was not the best. Highly disorganized institution. No reprimands for employees misusing funds. Supervisor shows favoritism. No one legitimately works and has a ton of gossip. I think working in a factory is better.

job_title: Instructor of Mathematics in Jefferson City, MO
pros: For teaching and campus work, there are small class sizes so you can get to know your students very well.
cons: Very low pay, unless you are an administrator. Terrible health insurance benefits. Revolving door of administrators so there is a constant cycle of nothing getting improved.

review_title: Amazing people, but poor communication and few resources
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jefferson City, MO
pros: Amazing people work there from entry level secretaries to professors and administrators.  Even with the occasional "bad apple" people overwhelmingly care about the students and making a difference.  Most students are kind and friendly, and the local community does not give them nearly enough credit.  Even with the cons, the students will make you want to come back every day and that is why LU has so many long term employees despite compensation issues.  Great fringe benefits like free undergraduate tuition for employees, half of graduate tuition, generous vacation package, and MOSERS retirement.
cons: One of the lowest paying colleges in the state/nation for both faculty and staff, and a surprising number of people put in over 40 hours to get things done.  Your experience here will vary greatly depending on what department you are in and who your supervisor is.  No technical or leadership training is available.  There is constant reorganization and change, and students often complain that navigating services is unnecessarily convoluted.

review_title: Great Heritage, Dynamic New President, Money Woes
pros: Lots of room for moving into new projects, writing & publishing.  Small class sizes, some flexibility for online office hours if you teach online
cons: very low salaries and not much incentive to help you get a raise. Basically, you better be prepared to hold a second job if you want to teach here.  Communication from administration indicates they are trying to make the campus a better place but you never hear about changes until they are done, and then it's a "live with it" notice via email.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jefferson City, MO
pros: It's a diverse place to work that allows you academic freedom to help shape our future by working with great students. The campus is historic and sits in  Missouri's capitol city which makes it a beautiful place to be.
cons: There aren't many people that leave their positions so while you can advance if you're a professor. It may be difficult if you're looking for other leadership roles on campus.

review_title: Multicultural and educational opportunities but maybe not the best place to work for advancement
pros: Benefits (including the opportunity for free classes) and pay were good for that region of the county, professors and staff that I worked with were generally supportive and allowed autonomy in the workplace, flexible work schedule
cons: Management seemed clueless about what was happening on a day to day basis in academics, little in the way of training for support personnel, no opportunity for advancement, a generally dysfunctional work culture

job_title: Assistant Professor in Jefferson City, MO
pros: Cost of living is low in Jefferson City, Historically Black University with a lot of history, great marching band, cheap rents if you live in JC
cons: Sadly this institution is terribly managed and has no transparency. Provost & president left, faculty are paid and treated very poorly, do not expect much support financially or otherwise.

review_title: A good job for a student
job_title: Supplemental Instructor in Jefferson City, MO
pros:
The Center for Academic Support Services (the only department I can speak for) was ran quite well.
Interesting work, good people, flexible hours.
cons: The stress level changes dramatically depending on when in a semester it is, and can be quite high around midterms and finals.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Jefferson City, MO
pros: Small campus setting and colorful school history fosters fruitful student and alumni networking.
cons: Cronyism, nepotism, mishandling of funds, rampant misuse of power.

job_title: Office Assistant in Jefferson City, MO
pros: great managers great communication and great leadership
cons: I wish the job would have paid a little bit more

job_title: Research Assistant in Jefferson City, MO
cons: Very low compensations. No benefits at all
